pros: Lovely residents and provided exceptional care to them.
cons: Organisational structure appeared to be ineffective, there was lack of adequate training, a lot of work to do for low pay and the expectations was unreasonable for a new member of staff. They do not allow you to make mistakes, if you do your looked down on and told off. The manager was overly picky over very little things and appeared to exaggerate and twisted the truth to suit, it made it a toxic work environment. Management also appeared clicky by backing each other up. Just as I was leaving, I was given a new laptop and tablet to use. I could have done with it months before and also the management structure changed for Activities, so I suspect whoever takes my job on will have a much easier ride in comparison, it wouldn’t be hard for another manager to be better than the one that was managing myself. I tried to raise my concerns but it fell on deaf ears and was white washed over. I was also accused of breaching policies by using my phone once at work at the start of the day for 5 minutes when I had a serious family dilemma to attend to. Shows how you are treated as a number rather than a person.

review_title: If you want to lose your soul work for MHA
pros:
Fantastic Colleagues at the face of service. Chaplaincy, Music Therapy and our Carers. 
Head Office have a few golden nuggets.
If their were honest people at the top, who live the values and cared for Staff as much as we are for residents there wouldn't be a better place than MHA
cons:
HR directorate seem to be the rotting head of the fish, policies are used and abused dependent on the person they are dealing with. ELT and their clicks are only thinking of their own benefits and safety and ticking boxes to not be liable whilst making people suffer. 
Racism is rife , having an EDI network doesn't make it right. (Again a tick box exercise)
Seems to be full of management who are furthering their own agendas and becoming more and more dictatorial this includes blocking channels of communication that aren't in his close network of dictators.
 All the good ones who pushed, challenged and spoke up for residents and the MHA values have been forced out strategically or through pure fatigue of trying.
Many who have left bare the scars won't even keep in touch as they say that after buying into the vision, values and giving their all to MHA, when you are forced out , the place you loved so much then feels traumatic even to recollect on whatever good you saw. PTSD is probably the reward for giving your soul to MHA.
